name: Grand Mercure Beijing Central

reviews.title: Great value, friendly and conveniently located hotel
reviews.text: I booked the marco polo hotel using airline network and for £68 per room per night including breakfast it was by far the cheapest price. The hotel is 5 minutes walk from a Tube station and a shopping mall is also close by. Due to Beijing being so big and the sights so spread out we found being close to the tube extremely convenient and at appox 30p to use the tube a cheap option to get around. The reception is beautiful and all staff were very friendly and helpful even allowing us to leave our cases there for 2 days whilst travelling to Xian. On our first 2 nights stay we were upgraded to the continental suite which was on the 10th floor. The only real difference to standard rooms was a larger bathroom and shower cubical. The rooms were spacious with extremely confortable beds. You have a mini bar and free water along with all the usual free toiletries. The breakfast was lovely with a choice of fruit, breads, meats, cooked breakfast, cereals etc etc what you would expect from a 3-4 start hotel. My husband and I would certainly stay there again and would recommend it to our freinds and family.

Got a great rate for the Corporate Floor from the Marco Polo's internet site. Included breakfast, laundry and pressing service, afternoon tea, evening drinks, chocolates on the pillow, etc. Room, bed, shower, internet access, all great. Check-in and check-out very efficient. Hotel staff very helpful in getting taxis and ensuring destination was understood by the driver. Hotel is situated between two subway lines - 3 minute walk to either stop. Second floor restaurant a little slow but reasonable prices. All in all, I highly recommend based on my experience.
reviews.title: Great stay for business travel

reviews.text: Hotel is clean and quite well situated.No hotel meets all normal criteria for location in Beijing, and this one is fine for taxis to central sites, and for Summer Palaces. For Chaoyang (entertainment district= red light area in a very mild way) it's a bit of a hike. Room on 9th floor had queen bed and was a no-smoking room.

Grand Mercure Hotel Xidan, Beijing (formerly the Marco Polo Beijing) is a 4 star hotel located in the Xidan district, about 15 minutes walk from the Forbidden City. There are several shopping malls located nearby, and a metro station is only 5 minutes walk away.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I was travelling with my parents, and my sister with her husband and 7 months old baby. By pure luck, I managed to book very cheap rooms because of a 3 days super sale on their website, so we ended up paying around 350 rmb (abt US$50) per night including tax. This price is a real bargain, so it's worthwhile checking their website for future promotions. Despite booking such cheap rooms, the hotel offered my sister and her family a free upgrade to a slightly larger room, because they were travelling with the baby. We really appreciated this nice gesture.

reviews.text: We stayed at the hotel for 3 nights in September 2009. We found it to be quiet, modern, very comfortable and with great service and overall excellent value. Beijing is a large city so it is impossible to be perfectly located for all attractions, however we were able to walk to Tiananmen Square (about 30 minutes walk) and from there to the Forbidden City. The area felt very safe. Concierge can also get you a cab quickly and the cabs are very cheap.

reviews.title: This hotel has convenient location, comfortable room & great breakfast.

reviews.text: Actually, I'm still staying at the hotel, and I agree with most of the reviews--this is a comfortable hotel with attentive and helpful staff. The breakfast buffet is generous and offerings vary daily (although weekend staff don't get you coffee very quickly and didn't offer any cream--but the weekday staff are superb), the Cantonese restaurant had great food at reasonable prices (although there was a loud--in fact literally--with an amplified microphone--party full of drunk men near to vomiting as they passed our table, which is weird in a restaurant where someone puts your napkin on your lap for you), and the rooms are comfy and well-appointed with fluffy towels and good pillows. Do note that the free wifi touted on the website applies only to the lobby and executive lounge--in the rooms there is only ethernet and for a cost. The hotel is bordering on luxury, as one reviewer remarked, but fails to reach that because it is visibly shabby and aging throughout--the carpet in our room and in the hallways is heavily stained, tiles on the floor near the restaurant are coming up or missing, the walls are scuffed, etc--basically one big updating of the surfaces would make a huge difference in one's sense of the quality of the hotel. I would happily stay here again despite these small problems, and I recommend the hotel itself wholeheartedly. It is a mere 5 minute walk to two subway lines and a 10 minute walk to another, between the two of which you can cover much of the city.
reviews.title: Great hotel--terrible tour desk.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: But avoid at all costs the "tour desk" in the lobby. We were quoted, in writing on a sheet on the desk, a price for a private tour of the Great Wall and Ming Tombs. The cost was on the steep side but we were strapped for time and decided it was worth the convenience. We were then told we must pay in cash, which we did--foolishly, I'm afraid, so that was our stupidity. The tour was perfectly fine--the tour guide was friendly and helpful, the driver a bit all over the road but not unusually so. However, on our return to the center of the city, the tour guide offered to make a special stop for us at the Olympic buildings--we thanked him but said no, we were tired. Then he got on the phone and we recognized the words for "2 Americans". Without being asked, we were suddenly pulled into an unplanned stop--at a "historic teahouse/silk museum" we had not requested at which we were treated to an aggressive (even by Beijing standards) sales pitch and insistence on purchasing silk goods on display. We left quickly (and politely) without purchasing and waited in the car for the tour guide, who did not follow us out but spent the next 20 minutes on his cell phone in the lobby. Things went from bad to worse when he finally rejoined us, offered another teahouse which we rejected, and then relented to take us back to the hotel. The sheet on the tour desk which was shown us for pricing that morning did/does not mention something we found out only at this point--that all the entrance fees to each site (two for one part of the Wall, one to go up, one to go down, and then for the tombs) were NOT included in the price we had paid in cash at the outset (and these totaled 1/3 again the price of the tour, so they weren't minor). We were then told in the car that we had to pay these fees to our guide, again in cash, immediately. We had just enough cash on us to cover this plus a small tip, luckily. We apologized profusely for the small tip but explained that we hadn't been told there would be further fees and hadn't brought much cash. The guide said it was okay by him, but the (non-English speaking) driver would be furious and we really needed to tip more, so he would be happy to take us to an ATM to get more money! This after we had asked the tour desk staffperson and she had informed us that tips were optional, and said if we were *especially* happy, to tip the amount we already had (10%). We of course did not consent to this. When we got to the hotel, the tour guide took us in to the tour desk staffer so we could "tell her how he was as a guide" (while he stood there); she told us that although the sheet she provided didn't mention added costs for our tour, that entry fees were only included in the cost of the *other* tours on the sheet--and that we had been an "emergency" tour because we had come in after 8am (although she never mentioned either of these things when demanding our cash earlier, and neither is mentioned in any way on the information sheet). By this point between disingenuous apologies both were beginning to create contradictory excuses and we were too exhausted to fight with logic. We're taking it as our own stupidity for not having insisted more on what was presented in writing and on challenging the "cash only" requirement while sitting in a well-stocked business office in a big hotel, but we thought we should warn others. I've had tour guides (in larger bus tours) who were clearly on the "take" before, but nothing like this in terms of direct pressure and embarrassment--and both the guide and staffer told us that their company was unaffiliated with the hotel so there was no recourse that way (this was one of their excuses for the added costs)--apparently the tour company just rents the space in the lobby (although the hotel lists this as one of their services). Caveat emptor.

reviews.text: I booked this hotel three months in advance through hotel.com and got a wonderful deal. The room is impeccable, comfortable, bordering luxurious : ) and the service is phenomenal: I borrowed their wrapping tape right off the concierge desk; asked for an adaptor and a sewing kit in all different occasions and their response rate, friendliness and efficiency are phenomenal! Unfortunately I didn't get a chance to use the gym and the pool, but was extremely impressed by the facilities (including spa-like shower area and sauna) when I checked it out. HIGHLY recommend it!

Marco Polo? Marco Polo!
reviews.text: 1) Spacious rooms, nice linen, and the concierge will be quite keen to upgrade you if you are not happy with your room. All you need to do is politely complain, and they will come to your aid. We got a room facing an enormous construction site, and since they work 24/7 in Beijing, we decided to complain. We got a fancy suite facing the main street, which was quiet; the bathrooms are quite large with both a shower and a bath-tub (bath tub not reccomended though - black spots spitting out of the faucet and yellow water put us off a bit)

reviews.title: New hotel in Beijing
reviews.text: 2) People are bangig on about location in some of the reviews. I seriously don't understand the complaint. Mind you, Beijing is an enormous city, and ridicolously crowded, which in itself makes it a hard place for pedestrians; furthermore, taxi's are affluent and so cheap that it is hard to believe. We never paid more than about 2 USD almost anywhere we went, so in my world, it doesn't really matter where you are in this city, as long as you are somewhere inside the city, and not out by the airport or near a cest pit somewhere. Taxi is your key, and the easiest way to get around. Bring a map to show to cab drivers with names in Chinese - it will make everything a lot easier.

reviews.title: Lovely Boutique Hotel in the Middle of Smog City

description: The Grand Mercure Xidan Beijing is located in the commercial and retail heart of Beijing, walking distance from Tiananmen Square and only 45 min from the airport. The hotel offers 290 rooms featuring city views, as well as a cafe restaurant, lobby lounge, fitness centre and swimming pool. With exceptional service and facilities, the hotel is perfect for that special weekend holiday as well as an ideal conference venue for business travellers.
